entry.title: Calculation View Features of 2025 QRC4
entry.content:
Within the time frame of 2025 Q4, several new calculation view features have been released in SAP Business Application Studio when connected to SAP HANA Cloud database QRC4. Some of these features are highlighted below. You can find examples that illustrate the individual features here. An overview of features of other releases can be found here.

Key Indicators

To support the decision on which columns a join should be defined or which cardinality should be set the key column indicator highlights columns that belong to the key of a data source:

Information about key columns is shown in join nodes and derived from underlying data sources. For table data sources the information is taken from the primary key information of the table. For calculation view data sources the key information is taken from the Semantics node. 

The key information is propagated within a model but not to the Semantics node, so that the decision about the Semantics node key can be done explicitly.
 
Use the key information to decide about join columns and join cardinality
 

Option to Control Column Pruning Behavior

The instantiation logic of calculation views reduces the number of processed columns and data sources based on the query. If instead a relational behavior similar to SQL views is intended all columns can be tagged with the property "Keep Flag". To simplify this, the option "Column Pruning Behavior" can be set to "OFF" which automatically sets the Keep Flag property for all columns:
 
Forcing additional columns into the aggregations can change the results, lead to higher resource consumption, and a decrease in performance. Therefore, Column Pruning Behavior should only be set to "OFF" if SQL view behavior is required.

Use this option to quickly compare the results with and without instantiation logic or if you want to mimic SQL behavior.
 

Open objects in Data Lineage and Impact Analysis Display

When analyzing the consumed objects of a calculation view (data lineage) or the consumers of a calculation view (impact analysis) the displayed objects of the same HDI container can now be opened in their associated editors:
 
Data Lineage
Impact Analysis
Data Lineage and Impact Analysis are available via the context menu of calculation view files:
 
Use this option to better understand the objects that are involved in lineage and impact analysis
 

Column Lineage SQL Function

Function SYS.GET_CALC_VIEW_COLUMN_DEPENDENCIES returns the base columns of individual calculation view columns. With this it becomes easy to track, for example, from which table a certain measure is coming.
 
IN Parameters
The parameters of the SQL function are:
- schema name of the calculation view to analyze
- the calculation view name
- the column to track or an empty string
- the option 'BASE' that defines the output details of the function
 
If the column name is left empty (''), all columns are treated as target columns.
Currently only the option BASE is available which omits intermediate objects and reports the underlying tables only.
 
System privilege CATALOG READ is required to execute the function.
 
Use this function to increase the insights into the behavior of the calculation view and to answer data auditing questions

MDS Cubes

Input parameters can now be used as client values during currency or unit conversion:

The input parameters do not have to be materialized when the mode Query Execution is selected.

The star joins can now include left outer joins:

and also restricted columns can be added to the MDS Cube:

Option Keep MDS Cube During Deployment

Per default MDS Cubes are newly created during deployment. This means that data that have been loaded into MDS Cubes will be deleted.
 
Set the Keep MDS Cube During Deployment flag if you want to keep the MDS Cube and thus the data also during redeployment:

 


This ensures that reporting on and loading of the MDS Cube can continue as before the redeployment.
 
Deployment of the calculation view is still possible as long as the calculation view changes would not lead to a situation in which the MDS Cube could not be loaded anymore. A redeployment will fail if it would lead to a MDS Cube that is not loadable anymore,  e.g., a column used in the MDS Cube is removed from the calculation view.

While the MDS Cube itself will not be modified by a successful redeployment of the calculation view when the flag is set, changed meta data such as changed hierarchies will be reflected when using the MDS Cube in SAP Analytics Cloud.
 
If the Keep MDS Cube During Deployment flag is set no changes to the MDS Cube are allowed and editing of the MDS Cube is blocked. If you want to edit the MDS Cube, unset the flag. Future redeployments will delete the data.
 
Use flag to ensure continuous reporting on MDS Cubes across deployments

entry.title: Re: Correct approach to get the staging and active data i...
entry.content:
Hi Chandra,

As I understood from your question, the base idea of what you want to achieve is to add your workflow a custom column which represents the status of MSTAE, MMSTA changes (whether the fields are changed or NOT).

If it is the case, you must read both inactive and snapshot (the active data before CR is created for the change scenario) and compare them.

Of course, there are several ways to do that but as you mentioned, you need to read the data from both data source points using these read modes;

  • if_usmd_model_ext=>gc_readmode_default [for staging]
  • if_usmd_db_adapter=>gc_readmode_no_inact [for snapshot]

Best Regards,

Beykan
